case_vignette: A sexually active 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 7-day history of itching in the area of his genitals. He also reports burning on micturition. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with oral metformin. Pelvic examination shows tender, atrophic white papules on the glans and prepuce, with erythema of the surrounding skin. The urinary meatus is narrowed and sclerotic.
question: Which  is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Renal and Genitourinary System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing itching around my private parts for the past week and burning when I pee.
How old are you?
I am 37 years old.
Do you have any history of kidney or urinary problems?
No, but I have type 2 diabetes that is under control.
Are you currently taking any medications for your type 2 diabetes or any other conditions? If so, what are they?
Yes, I am taking oral metformin for my type 2 diabetes.
Do you have a family history of kidney or urinary disorders?
I don't know, you didn't ask me about that before.
Apologies for that oversight. Do you have a family history of any medical problems?
No, that isn't mentioned in my medical history.
**Final Diagnosis:** Urinary tract infection (UTI)
